Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery open vessel, possibly a lekanis or skyphos; interior glazed black; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of animal friezes; from top: two legs or paws, to left, above dilute line; deer or goat (pointed nose with added red markings on neck, back and under belly; stump tail) and seated feline with head turned back and raised left paw (neck, body, and paws remaining; red on neck, body and under belly), both to left; triple dot band (but double below deer or goat) between dilute bands; parts of seven thin rays.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Execrable work; 'deer' has two legs pointing backwards.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 472, no. B812)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0795) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 91, pl. I, no. 16)
Hogarth, Lorimer & Edgar 1905 / Naukratis 1903 (p. 121, pl. V, no. 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
